awd_titl_txt: Science Education for Excellence and Equity in Chicago (SEEEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
In collaboration with a wide variety of non-profit organizations (Project SYNCERE, Little Village Environmental Justice Organization, Chicago Freedom School, Chicago Botanic Garden, Friends of the Chicago River, Institute for Latino Progress), the University of Chicago-Illinois seeks to prepare 30 new science teaching fellows (TFs) while building the capacity of 10 master teaching fellows (MTFs) to be leaders in urban science education.  The project will address the professional development of all participants through a three-pronged mechanism which emphasizes (a) content-specific information that focuses on Next Generation Science Standards, (b) culturally relevant practices, and (c) teacher inquiry/research.  The work will be performed in partnership with the Chicago Public Schools.

Recent graduates, career changers, and in-service Master Teachers will be provided with (a) a broad range of science concentrations including biology, chemistry, earth and space science, environmental science, and physics, (b) a unique urban perspective on science education that emphasizes diverse learning assets and equity, and (c) professional development opportunities within a community of faculty, teacher-leaders, and non-profit organizations.  TFs will be prepared for licensure while earning a Master's in Instructional Leadership: Science Education, learning to teach and examine their practice as it relates to teaching, and learning within specific communities.  MTFs will learn to conduct practitioner research and lead teacher inquiry groups examining essential and enduring challenges in STEM teacher practice and student learning. Formative and summative evaluation will focus on analysis of both qualitative and quantitative data related to degree and licensure attainment, the various teaching practice activities (lesson plans, participant surveys, etc.), and progress in meeting the overarching project goals. In doing so, the project will advance knowledge and understanding of the role played by community-based partnerships of university faculty, school teacher-leaders, and local non-profit entities in enhancing teacher education and development, and the circumstances that promote their success. The results of this work will be presented at national meetings of the American Educational Research Association and the American Association of Colleges of Teacher Education.

por.por_cntn:
Science Education for Excellence and Equity in Chicago (Project SEEEC) was a science teacher education and leadership initiative beginning in October 2014 as part of the former Noyce Track 3, which combined both Teaching Fellows (TFs) and Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs). Project SEEEC was a partnership among University of Illinois Chicago (UIC) Department of Curriculum and Instruction, several UIC science departments in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, and Chicago Public Schools (CPS) working with several Chicago non-for-profit organizations:

(1)   To address the critical shortage of qualified high school science teachers teaching in urban areas, in high-need science areas, and in high-need schools;

(2)   To tackle the insufficient leadership at the high school science level by preparing master teachers to be transformative leaders of urban science education at local, regional, and national levels;

(3)   To advance the broader social and equity commitment of preparing a diverse workforce of science teachers prepared to build on strengths and address the needs of urban youth.

Regarding the first goal, Project SEEEC supported 34 TFs and 9 MTFs who were representative in various ways of the students served by CPS. Project SEEEC emphasized the hard-to-staff content areas of chemistry and physics with 62% of TFs licensed to teach in those areas and the remainder licensed in biology or environmental sciences. Leveraging the Project SEEEC model allowed us to secure supplemental funding from the U.S. Department of Education to support 10 additional new teachers bringing the total of new science teachers supported by the Project SEEEC model to 44.  Across all TFs, MTFs, and other teachers supported by the Project SEEEC model, 10 years since the start of this project, the majority of the 53 science teachers continue to work in the partner district, CPS.

Regarding the second goal of leadership development, MTFs and TFs have developed into science education leaders in Chicago and nationally. After exceeding their teacher commitments, three MTFs and one TF from Project SEEEC have earned PhDs in science education. Two of these fellows and are now tenure-track professors of science education and teacher educators, one is currently a postdoctoral research fellow in engineering education, and one continues to teach in our partner district while also occupying a national teacher leadership role. Six more MTFs and four more TFs continue to make progress towards the completion of a PhD in science education at UIC. Moreover, two MTFs have been promoted to STEM instructional coaches in public high schools in Chicago and another received the 2021 Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching (PAEMST). Another MTF was recognized as Teacher of the Year by our partner Friends of the Chicago River and a TF won both local and national awards for her efforts in environmental education. Several MTFs and now TFs regularly serve as cooperating teachers for the UIC MEd in Science Education program that has been the hub of the TF teacher preparation. Project SEEEC TFs and MTFs have contributed to disseminating what we learned by presenting at dozens of national, regional, and local conference and professional development sessions and co-authoring several manuscripts in research journals, practitioner venues, and books.

Research manuscripts from Project SEEEC have been published in Science Education, the Journal of Research in Science Teaching, and Cognition and Instruction, among others. These publications disseminate much of what we have learned from Project SEEEC and form its intellectual outcome. Specifically, we have learned that community-based organizations can play an important role in the education of community-centered science educators by complementing university coursework and fieldwork experiences and prompting new teachers to see the strengths and complexities of urban communities (Varelas et al., 2018). We have also explored some of the ways that new teachers navigate the relationships between equity and excellence as they make instructional decisions in schools that serve students with similar backgrounds and experiences (Varelas et al., 2023). We have articulated some of the pedagogical and science disciplinary commitments that are involved in new science teachers negotiating contested definitions of equity in urban STEM education (Morales-Doyle et al., 2021). One of the implications emerging from these various publications and the practice of science teachers and teacher educators in Project SEEEC is that organizing instruction around community priorities while attending to science standards is a difficult process for new teachers. More importantly, we have learned that this difficult work can be successfully supported by strong relationships with more experienced colleagues, community organizations, and teacher educators (Morales-Doyle et al., 2018; Segura et al., 2019; Varelas et al., 2018).


Last Modified: 02/04/2025
Modified by: Maria Varelas
por.por_txt_cntn:

(2) To tackle the insufficient leadership at the high school science level by preparing master teachers to be transformative leaders of urban science education at local, regional, and national levels;


(3) To advance the broader social and equity commitment of preparing a diverse workforce of science teachers prepared to build on strengths and address the needs of urban youth.

Regarding the second goal of leadership development, MTFs and TFs have developed into science education leaders in Chicago and nationally. Two of these fellows and are now tenure-track professors of science education and teacher educators, one is currently a postdoctoral research fellow in engineering education, and one continues to teach in our partner district while also occupying a national teacher leadership role.
